Stephen King is an acclaimed American author widely recognized for his contributions to horror, supernatural fiction, suspense, and fantasy. Born on September 21, 1947, in Portland, Maine, US, King's childhood was marked by a love for reading, which eventually led him to become one of the best-selling authors in history.

King began writing short stories at a young age, honing his skills and developing his unique voice. He graduated from the University of Maine in 1970 with a Bachelor of Arts degree in English, later earning a Master of Arts in English from Boston University in 1971.

King's first published novel, Carrie, a psychological horror about a bullied high school girl with telekinetic powers, was published in 1974. The book became an instant success, establishing King as a major figure in the genre. He followed this with his first major work of horror, The Shining, which was published in 1977 and adapted into a critically acclaimed film in 1980, starring Jack Nicholson and Sharon Stone.

Since then, King has written over 60 novels and 200 short stories, earning numerous awards and accolades, including the prestigious Bram Stoker Award, World Fantasy Award, and Edgar Award. Some of his other best-known works include IT, Misery, The Stand, The Dark Tower series, and Under the Dome.

Beyond his literary success, King has appeared on various television shows and specials, where he shares insights into his creative process and discusses his passion for storytelling. King's popularity is further solidified by the immense success of the films and television adaptations of his works, with notable productions including The Shawshank Redemption, The Green Mile, and the TV series Supernatural.

Stephen King's life and career have had a significant impact on popular culture, and he continues to be a towering figure in contemporary literature, with a fanbase that extends across the globe. His dedication to writing and storytelling has cemented his legacy as one of the most influential and prolific authors of our time.
